intro: Boechera beckwithii, commonly known as the Sierra Wallflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, showy flowers and pinnately compound leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in mountainous regions, thriving in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers, which range in color from white to pink, bloom in early spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Boechera beckwithii is also noted for its ability to tolerate drought conditions, making it well adapted to its arid habitat.
